tn261.description: FERIC TN-261 loader-forwarder regression (Vancouver Island, 1994) for Madill 3800 support machines.
notes: Delay-free detailed timing; apply utilisation separately if needed.
Log-linear fit with piece-size exponent ≈0.41 and distance exponent ≈−0.60.
references: FERIC TN-261 (1994). Loader-forwarding productivity study, coastal BC.

adv2n26.description: ADV-2 No. 26 (Kosicki 2001) Trans-Gesco TG88 clambunk and John Deere 892D-LC loader-forwarder support role.
references: FPInnovations ADV-2 No. 26 (2001). Evaluation of a Trans-Gesco TG88 clambunk skidder working in northwestern BC.

adv5n1.description: ADV-5 No. 1 (Kosicki & Dyson 2004) Madill 3800 loader-forwarder regressions by slope class.
notes: Payload and utilisation sourced from Table 6 (2.77 m³/cycle, 93 %).
references: FPInnovations ADV-5 No. 1 (2004). Using mechanized systems to harvest second-growth forests in coastal BC.

barko450.description: FERIC TN-46 Barko 450 live-heel loader (interior BC) handling grapple-skidded decks and Washington 78 yarder wood.
notes: Production capped by truck supply (≈12 off-highway loads per day).
Live-heel grapple facilitated multi-stem handling but waits/moves dominated downtime.
references: FERIC TN-46 (1982). Evaluation of Barko 450 Loader.

kizha2020.description: Kizha et al. (2020) northern California biomass landing loader study (Thunderbird 840W) comparing hot vs. cold loading.
notes: Hot loading: utilisation ≈55 %, delays driven by yarder rigging and log-truck batches (33 % of time, $33/PMH).
Cold loading: utilisation ≈7 %, loader idled 77 % of the time waiting for empty roll-off bins (delay cost ≈$89/PMH).
Use this preset to gauge the utilisation penalty when biomass hauling is decoupled from sawlog loading.
references: Kizha, A.R. et al. 2020. Comparing Hot and Cold Loading in an Integrated Biomass Recovery Operation. Forests 11(385).
